segments.text: For example, they'd be sending frantic cables from Vietnam for various spare parts when lo and behold they had maybe a year's supply of them at Cam Ranh Bay in a depot that they hadn't identified or categorized or picked up on their records or what have you.
And situations like that, just too numerous to even mention.
No kidding.
Absolutely.

Cameron Bay, the stuff would arrive over there in boxes and they would stack them up and put them out in the open, cover them up with tarpaulins and nobody ever made any effort to determine what the hell was under these tarps.
Was it needed, was it in, and even with an identification code some of the stuff that was needed for
for aircraft that were out of, off of readiness status.
Some of the boxes were imprinted with red dots and this sort of thing to indicate priority cargo that was needed for deadline vehicles or aircraft.
We found a lot of deadline cargo shipments under these tarpaulins.
The stuff was so marked and
There should have been immediately when it arrived in the command and came off of the airplane, it was all hauled by air freight over there.
It should have gone right to a point where it was disseminated and identified as to who had requisitioned it and what the purpose was.
But those kind of things are just due to lack of management attention.
And it's a constant reminder of an old saying that a commander that I remember during the war
said that a unit does well only those things that the boss checks up on and that's so true.
Patton didn't say that, he's attributed to having said that, but originally I think that General Courthouse Lee said that.
He was a rather infamous commander of the U.S. service forces
under Eisenhower in Europe.
Nobody liked him.
He was a very high-powered Episcopal lay reader.
But he made that statement, and I think old Courthouse Lee was right.

Well, anyway, it was a very bad situation, and the Secretary of Defense's office, I don't know who in the Secretary of Defense's office, said that in connection with this high-winder trip we made in 1966,
if we could get some shots of some of these bad examples on movie film.

So, when I arrived in the command, the deputy commander, General Abrams, who later was the commander general in Vietnam, I told Abe, and I had gone to the War College with Abe, so I knew him on a first-name basis.
I told him that SecDef's office wanted me to
wherever I could to put some pictures on film, movie film, of some of the logistic problems that we could help out with.
They said fine, so he assigned a combat cameraman and a crew of two other people with our team.
And as a matter of fact, we took pictures of almost everything.
Every time I'd look up, these guys were taking pictures.
Finally, after it all got done, a 45-minute edited film was made of the trip.
As a matter of fact, I've got a copy of it in my personal records.
No kidding.
Yes, I have.
It's a sound... No, it's not a soundtrack.
I put a soundtrack on it.
I dubbed a soundtrack in.
I went up to Long Island to the Signal Corps Depot and dubbed in a soundtrack on it.
So now it does have a soundtrack?
Yeah, it does have a soundtrack.
Can I see that movie?
Yeah, you could.
I've got it.
It's stored at home, and I don't have a projector, but I'll arrange some time to come down and show it to you.
No, why don't you just send it to me?
Okay.
Because I have tons of projectors at the university.
Yeah, I'd really like to see that film because I teach Vietnam, and I'd like to see it for my own edification.
Yeah.
Okay, the film, I'm not sure the whole, I know I opened the film with a narrative, and maybe, but there's not sound on every little scene.
I'll do that.
I'll send it to you.
I'd love to see it.
And it was, it's, not many horrible examples are shown.
It wound up, I didn't edit it.
I didn't do the editing.
And they didn't show some of the bad things that I wanted to show.
But it's a pretty good picture of some of the depots and the riverine force in Vietnam.
This was a very, I think one of the most capable operations in Vietnam was that riverine force.
And I spent several days with them.
Where about?
On the river there, and up and down the river with them.
Went on patrols with them.
Saigon River?
Yeah, yeah.
And went on patrols with them.
Matter of fact, we almost had an accident flying off of one of those ships.
There was a tail rotor on our chopper, just barely nicked a mast on the damn thing.
And we'd have gone right in the water if it had hit it.
But it just scraped it.
Because the pilot was just utterly scared to death.
He didn't know whether to go ahead and go on and lift off or what.
Because we heard it real loud.
But anyway, let's get back to Abrams and Westmoreland now.
So Abrams gave me a lot of cooperation.
Westmoreland, I don't know.
I think there's a lot of truth in what CBS said about Westmoreland.
Just recently, yeah?
Yes, just recently.
And Westmoreland, of course, is very unhappy about it.
That he falsified some documents.
Yeah, and a lot of people have risen to his defense.
I really felt in 1966, when I was over there, that we were going to win this war.
that we could win this war, and I felt, and as do the strategic people, and I certainly agree with them, that the failure that we made, and that Westmoreland made, was not insisting.
We had enough troops over there to win.
Oh, goodness knows we had enough support over there to win.
We had enough logistics support.
It's the only war, really, in recent, in all our history, and of course, I'm for our
troops in the field and our fighting forces really getting the very best of everything.
This is the only war where we went, where Westmoreland wanted to go better than first class.
You know?
He wanted to do better than first class.
And in many respects they did.
For example, in rations.
They, all of Vietnam, the subsistence was issued in Vietnam on the basis
125 percent of the authorized ration, they got 25 percent more food per capita in Vietnam than they were supposed to get.
It was 125 percent of everything, the ration.
And wherever it could be done, in other words, even with a unit out in the bush on patrol,
they tried to bring them in thermotainers every day, at least one hot meal.
And some unit commanders in some outfits tried, in addition to one hot meal, also tried to bring them ice cream once a day in these thermotainers.
And they did, they absolutely did, because I was out in some of the units on patrol and at lunchtime we had ice cream and we had hot fried chicken and so forth.
I'll never forget at Da Nang, going in the, at the Marine Depot in Da Nang.
The officers club was a beautiful little club they built with a huge picture window.
You could sit in the officers club in the evening and watch an artillery duel.
through the picture window, you could see the artillery flashes way off in the horizon between our forces and the Viet Cong.
And at the briefing I got at Da Nang at this marine depot, this young officer, a marine first lieutenant, I think, or second lieutenant, was telling about his ice cream plant.
And he said, we're known as the Howard Johnsons of Vietnam.
He says, we make and serve daily.
eight different flavors of ice cream.
And he then enumerated chocolate vanilla, strawberry, pecan, and so forth.
Eight flavors of ice cream.
The Howard Johnsons of Vietnam.
This was in the briefing for a visiting general officer or an inspection team.
And the same sort of feeling prevailed everywhere.
You know, that we've got this, we've got that, and the best of everything, and it was better than first class.
Of course, life out in the bush on patrol and out in the rice paddy and fighting the comm, there's nothing first class about that.
And being shot and leeches and mosquitoes on you and that.

But everything else, back in the rear areas and the headquarters and the hotels in Saigon, the officer's club on top of the hotel there in Saigon, where you could also see artillery duels on the horizon at night while you're having a charcoal broil steak up there and all kinds of drinks.
And those sorts of things are directly related to command.
Directly related to command.
Westmoreland did not utilize in an efficient, military, cold-blooded military way the assets that he had.
He did not do it.
Can you give him an example?
Well, all the spare parts and all the maintenance supplies and everything were there.
they were there covered up with tarpaulins.
He didn't have somebody out there digging and doing this and doing that and expediting maintenance and keeping all these choppers ready to fly and the aircraft ready to fly.
There was a large percentage of our air support aircraft were down for maintenance on any given day.
A large support of our helicopters were down for maintenance on a given day.
and other vehicles and so forth.
I think the maintenance in the riverine force was better than any part in Vietnam.
And those sort of things ultimately reflect themselves in combat efficiency.
When you don't have a force well maintained and everything that you have is not capable to fight, you're not going to fight as well.
And you're not going to fight as effectively.
What did the Secretary of Defense say when you handed him your report and the film?

Well they were, you know, they were a little bit appalled and shocked and of course a lot of cables went back and forth and the command, you know, always takes a defensive posture and well we had some new personnel at Cameron Bay and these things were missed and we've initiated new procedures to do this and do that and so forth.
I think in Vietnam as a whole there were some broad strategic decisions.
This is my own personal opinion now that you probably can't lay in Westmoreland's lap.
But I think that we should have bombed or mined Haiphong a long, long time before we did.
Westmoreland would agree with you there.
Yeah, and we should have inflicted interdiction damage upon parts of North Vietnam.
to preclude them having the capability to move down into South Vietnam.
It was a difficult war because many times you had difficulty even identifying your enemy.
The con, you know, wearing their black pajamas and everything.
It was difficult to even identify them.
And I know even the choppers that I flew around in and any general officer, senior officer for that matter, was always a machine gunner sitting in each door.
And we would take off and then rise up immediately at about 1500 feet to get above small arms and accurate range before we'd start across country.
and these machine gunners would see somebody down there and there was a jungler or a rice paddy and they weren't real sure whether they were calm or not, but they'd fire a burst at them anyway.
Really?
Yeah, and I told this one kid one day, I said, you sure do have a nimble finger.
He said, well, he said, they look like calm to me.
I said, well, we're about fifteen, sixteen hundred feet above them and I can't identify them, but he was shooting at them and
But I think that these broad strategic decisions, I think they weren't made because there was some fear that the Red Chinese or the Soviets might intervene in some strategic way if we did.
I don't believe they would have.
No.
I don't believe they would have.
But I blame Westmoreland for not using what he had there.
And it was millions of tons of military equipment and hardware.
Could you compare Westmoreland and the type of man or commander he was with that of Creighton Abrams?
Westmoreland was a fancy Dan type of a guy that wants to you know be high and mighty and powerful and look real fancy and real glamour boy and sexy type and but he's not a gutty earthy down-to-earth
type individual.
I don't think he ever, I don't think the average G.I.
ever thought very much of Westmoreland.
And they did of Abrams.
Did in World War II of Abrams and in Vietnam.
But uh- Why?
Tell me about Abrams.
Tell me about Abrams.
You must have known him much better.
Yeah, I knew him a lot better.
I think when Abrams took over, he had inherited an impossible situation.
It was almost beyond rehabilitation or beyond saving.
We were not going to, we were apparently not going to make these broad strategic decisions.
We finally did bomb Hanoi and some of those places rather extensively, but it was a little too late then.
Abrams inherited, he improved the logistic situation tremendously in a short period of time.
He really did that.
But we were pretty far down the pike of being an unwanted, unwinnable war by the time Creighton Abrams took over.
If Creighton Abrams had gone in there when Westmoreland did, I think we'd have won that war.
Well, now let's answer the big question.
How could we have won that war, or why did we lose?
We lost that war because our commanders in the field, our highest commanders in the field, did not exert the all-out maximum effort that they should have exerted.
And we lost that war also because the will of our country was really not for winning that war.

with all the dissension at home and I think that the dissension at home affected the strategic planning and decisions that were not made about some of these things early in the war to bomb and mine Haiphong Harbor and bomb Hanoi or bomb the communication lines and other things.
I think that the problems at home
the unwelcomeness of the war and the unpopularity of the war.

And then I think, and you probably have heard a lot of people say this, I think that the war became extremely unpopular and unpalatable to every American, including the military Americans, because of the exposure of the war.
the media exposure of the war.
We had it in our bedrooms, in our living rooms, and in our dining rooms at every newscast period of every waking day.
And we only saw the good, the bad side of the war.
We panned in on the guys burning down the little villages and the Viet Cong refuge hoochies.
When they'd root them out and find them, then they'd burn them down so they wouldn't move in and occupy them again.
And we saw the little old ladies in the, holding the naked babies, sitting in the rice paddies crying.
Now this is what the news guys took the pictures of.
And you give anybody those pictures over and over and over again.
If we had had the same exposure to World War II that we had to Vietnam, it would have been just as unpopular, maybe far more unpopular.
If we had had in our living rooms and in our dining rooms

the pictures of the refugees on the Autobahns in Germany when the 3rd Armored Division was going by and the refugees stand there holding out their hands and begging for food and all this sort of thing.
Why, the American people would have just wretched.
And if we had seen some of the other things that went on, we didn't have any of this in Vietnam, but I don't know if anybody there mentioned it.
There was a hell of a lot of looting
in World War II on the part of the American soldiers.
If we'd have had a few pictures of that on the movies, on the television screens, this would have made it a very unpopular war.
I'm not saying that the press should not have been allowed in Vietnam, but the exposure, it did the thing.
We see the same thing now in Beirut today.
You see the same thing.
And the majority of American people
and I think it's generally a correct assumption, have assumed that Israelis are the vicious aggressor in this thing.
And I think Begin is a little bit on the madman side, or the side that he thinks he's the little Napoleon.
But if we'd have had the same exposure in World War II or World War I,
that we had in Vietnam, it would have been just as unpopular.
And God knows it would have been, the Civil War would have been far more unpopular if we'd have had the same exposure.
The same media exposure.
But I think we could have won Vietnam if we'd have had a Patton in command in Vietnam.
If we'd have had somebody with the mentality of Patton.
And Abrams did have the mentality of a Patton.
because Abrams was one of Patton's young, bright, brilliant combat commanders in World War II.
But Westmoreland was a fancy Dan.
I don't know that he falsified the reports of the Kong back to the JCS, but I wouldn't be a bit surprised if he thought it was enhancing his position.
He might have.
I don't trust the guy.
I really don't.
Okay, let's talk about your last job then, command of the Defense Personnel Support Center.
Yeah.
And what impact did Vietnam have on that?
Tremendous impact.
Tell me about it.
Because the buildup, of course, increased our requirements for everything, food and clothing.

I told you yesterday about the problems we had to get coverage of equipment and particularly clothing and combat equipment and combat clothing and tentage and all this sort of thing and even some medical items for the support of the troops in Vietnam where we had to because, and I relate this to what we've just been talking about, the unpopularity of the war
No legitimate, very few legitimate American businesses would even bid on the requirements of the military at the start of the Vietnam buildup.
Well, do you think that was because of what you said yesterday, the excellent economy, or was that because the war was unpopular in 1966?
I think it was a combination of both.
It was a combination of both.
I think the war was unpopular and becoming more so every day.
Plus, a booming economy.
And the businesses didn't want to interfere with their relationships, with their customers.
Everything was good.
And the Johnson administration had not put us on a wartime basis.
We wanted to have guns and butter, too.
He said that in a statement, I think.
And so the military was at the mercy of the will and the desire of business to help support the Vietnam effort.
It really, it's hard for me to say this, but I will say it, I think it slowed down our effort several months.
It slowed it down.
I know it slowed down the training in the reception centers in the United States.
Because they did not have the supplies.
Because we did not have.
They were not able to bring in as many people as quickly as they did because they didn't have clothing for them.
And then we went out on, they went out on the open market.
The reception centers were given local authority to go out into Sears and Robux and buy an army surplus stores and buy khaki uniforms and fatigue clothing
to have for the raw recruits when they came in to start basic training.
And we just didn't have it.
And because nobody would bid on it.

And we had to finally resort to this wartime authority that was passed in World War II of directed procurement, where we sent actually telegrams saying, you are hereby directed to manufacture such and such.
So it was a combination of the booming civilian economy
and the growing unpopularity of the war that made the logistic support of the training and the support effort almost an impossibility.
Why'd you retire from that job?
That seems like it was one of the most important jobs that you had throughout your entire career.
Right.
I would have had to retire
In December of that year, because of... December of 66?
Yeah, of 67, because of a requirement if you were five years in grade and you had not been promoted.
So if I had been promoted to my second star, I would not have retired.
But I was, I would have been five years in grade,
And while it didn't bother me really, my dedication to the job, there was a certain amount of bad feeling of not having been promoted.
And even though I was doing the job and everybody was, you know, saying what a great guy you were and great job you're doing and so forth and so on.

And this offer, the chairman of Scott, whom I got to know there in Philadelphia, I served in an honorary capacity on the Board of Directors of the Greater Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce when I was a commander.
I got that when I was in Northeast Philly at DISC.
He offered me this job at Scott to bring me in as a corporate vice president at the corporate level and with...

operational responsibility for the container division and the foam division and also with some responsibility in their research and i had consulted and given them some advice on a invention they had because of my knowledge with jet fuel scott made a polyurethane foam that they could control the pore size on the foam
And they did some experiment with it in race car tanks to pack the tank of a race car with this foam.
And you could take a 100-gallon tank and pack this Scott foam in it with 10-4ths to the inch.
And you could fill that 100-gallon tank, even though the tank was filled with this foam, you could fill that tank with 97 gallons of fuel.
You only lose 3% because of this foam.

If that tank were ruptured like in an accident that happened at Indianapolis at the start of the race three or four years before that, several cars caught on fire and a couple of guys were killed and so forth, you wouldn't have an explosion because the fire would not, the explosion would not move through that foam.
It would suppress an explosion.
And then I surmised and told them that I thought the same thing would happen in an aircraft tank.

If you'd pack that foam, I told Harry Dunning at a dinner party one night in mid-66, why don't you have your guys, they were working with Firestone, why don't you have them pack a wingtip tank of an airplane, pack it with cotton foam, fill it about half full of jet fuel, don't fill it all away, fill it about half fuel so there's vapor space on top of it, and I knew how explosive that was.
and fire a 30 caliber or a 50 caliber machine gun around to it.
They did.
They riddled it.
No explosion.
No fire.
Fantastic.
It was a dramatic, an absolute dramatic development.
So Harry Dunning called me at the office and said, God damn, he said, John, you really hit a jackpot.
And I said, what happened?
He said, well, you know, you told me you suggested a month or so ago when we were out at so-and-so's that
have them test this foam with aircraft tip tanks as we did yesterday.
And nothing happened, no explosion.
He said the Firestone people are ecstatic.
They've already called the Air Force at Wright-Patterson and they're going to go out there and give them a test in a day or two.
And he said, if you want to go, I can get you an invitation.
And I said, Harry, I don't know whether I ought to go in my position as a military.
And he said, well,

leave that up to you, but he said, so-and-so, I said, well, I know General so-and-so at Wright-Patterson, and he said, let me call him and get him to invite you to come out there, because you're interested in that, you know about it, and you're interested in the phone, so he did, and this Air Force guy called me, and I flew out there that weekend, and I saw this test out there.
Well, to make a long story short, the Air Force went into it in a big way.
They retrofitted all the F-105 fleet and packed foam in the tanks.
And we packed foam in the gunship tanks, the C-47s that were made into gunships.
We packed foam in some helicopter tanks.
To my knowledge, and they didn't do it in all the aircraft, but the F-105 fleet, they did.
They made a contract and did it in them.
ship the foam out there and so forth.
And Eaton did some here in the States, but they cut the foam in blocks, kind of like a crossword puzzle.
And they worked out the technique to open this inspection plate on the tank and just pack the foam in there and push it in and push it in.
To my knowledge, no aircraft that had its tank packed with foam and was penetrated by air-to-air
gunfire exploded in flight.
So I'm sure it was some pilots' lives saved, some aircrafts saved, because lots of them were hit.
And it would just leak out of there, see, but there wouldn't be any fire and explosion.
The peculiar thing about the phone, see, always in an explosion, we've always thought from a physics standpoint, we had to have two things present.
We had to have an explosive mixture.
We had to have the right mix of
of the explosive mixture, iron, oxygen, plus gas or gasoline vapors, plus a source of ignition.
But one thing that we never thought was crucial to that was space.
Space so far as being able to propagate the explosion.
So in this polyurethane foam with ten pores to the lineal inch, you've got a little
round pore space there that's open, no window on it, that is just a tenth of an inch or smaller in diameter, and that's not quite big enough to sustain an explosion and pass it along to the next one.
So I think there's really a new law of physics involved that not only do you have to have a physical explosive mixture and a source of ignition, you've got to have enough space.
And after I went to work for Scott, we talked to Boeing and tried to get to Douglas.
We talked to the Office of Transportation.
We talked to Detroit.
Ford Motor Company did pack some Thunderbirds with foam and some Lincoln Continentals with foam and drove them around the country and tested them.
One of them had a rear end accident and the tank ruptured.
There was no firing explosion.
I had a 66 T-bird, 67 T-bird, which I packed with foam, ordered a new tank packed with foam.
Detroit said even though the cost of the foam to pack a tank
would only be about $7 to pack the tank, the actual cost.
It would add about $125 to the cost of the automobile.
And they'd probably make it an option rather than put it off.
And they had all kinds of things.
And we finally wanted to get the Department of Transportation to specify that all school buses
Their tanks would be packed full.
And I think they're still working on that.
Scott's still working on that.
NASCAR, that controls all the race cars, has specified that all
petroleum distillate fuel race cars.
Their tanks would be packed with safety foam.
Other people since then had developed some things to make tanks and explosive proof.
Did you get a patent on this?
Did you ever get any revenue?
No, no.
Scott, Scott has a patent on the foam.
No, I just consulted with him on it.
So, Harry Dunning offered me this job and it was a, you know, it was a real good job.
I held a lot of money and I moved in at the
up on the corporate level with my name on the door and stainless steel plaque and it was quite a prestigious thing.
And where were you stationed?
I was in Philadelphia, right there in Philadelphia.
See their corporate headquarters are out at the airport in Philadelphia.
It was actually about five miles from my defense personnel support center.
So I retired that morning and retirement ceremonies were 11 o'clock.
And we had already moved off of the place and moved downtown at Society Hill Towers.
We lived on the Delaware River in this high rise downtown.
So after retirement ceremony, I got my car.
No, I went home, changed clothes, and then drove out to Scott.
Got there about 1.30 and walked in my office.
They already had my name on the door and everything.
And I went to work the same day.
No kidding.
Yeah.
the same damn day.
Then I would have...
Were you pretty bitter about the military?
No, not at all.
Not one bit.
And I haven't been since then.
And I stayed there for three years almost to the day till this situation here kind of opened up and Mrs. Adams was still living then.
She wanted me to come down and it was strictly a matter of economics as far as I was concerned.
We finally reached an accommodation and I acquired the sales company, the C.F.
Adams Company, and she gave me a few shares of the stock of the corporation, the manufacturing business.
I acquired some more of it from her at a bargain price about a year or two after I was here and then she passed away five years ago.
And are you the owner of this company?
And she left me some of the stock and I left the rest of her estate to her two living sisters.
So I wound up as the majority owner of the stock and have since acquired some more of it.
And it's not a big business, but it certainly has been here 66 years.
And so I've, from a personal financial standpoint, it's been very rewarding for me.
Now you've made it both in the military world.
You've climbed the ladder of success both in the military and in the civilian world.
Is there differences?
I mean, if you become a general,
in the military or if you become a corporate leader, is there a difference of how you do it?
No.
No difference.
I think the military is really a little bit ahead of business in down-to-earth techniques of command and operational control and command.
I think corporate business could really learn a few things by copying some of the techniques from the military.
I think in the corporate side of it, it's easier to do.
because of the lack of restraints on you.
The only restraints that you have from a corporate standpoint may be your board of governors if you're a minority in the thing, or your financial capability and so forth.
But my philosophy in taking a small business and gradually growing it, I could have expanded
I would have owed a hell of a lot of money if I had.
That's why I closed the tool department, because I found out it would cost me about $1,200,000 to buy some new forging hammers and furnaces and everything.
And our competitive position was such, I knew that we couldn't possibly pay for it.
And we were making a little money.
We were at least absorbing overhead from the rest of the plant.
And we had a good product, and people liked it.
But I've concentrated on making the small business strong.
And in gradually growing, we got bigger and bigger in gaskets.
We diversified strongly in gaskets.
We've become really a force to be reckoned with in the gasket market in Houston.
And we've added a lot of these other things that we buy for our own account and sell them.
We've gone into importing.
So I've done it slowly and gotten in the financial position to where we don't have to worry about cash flow.
We don't owe a dime.
I don't owe a bank a dime.
We don't owe a dime for the property.
We bought the property from the estate of Ms. Adams.
We paid that off last year.
We discount every damn bill that we owe.
As of this minute, I don't guess I owe a...
maybe two or three thousand dollars for stuff we haven't even received yet.
The minute an invoice comes in, we pay it.
We've got cash in the bank.
We've got really more cash on hand than we should.
We've got CDs earning money for that.
So I tried to get us in a very liquid position.
And that's the secret of a small business, to be liquid where you don't have to borrow money.
And it's just like in the military to be prepared and keep everything maintained so you're ready to respond in an emergency.
And I think the techniques of running a business or running a military command are identical.
It's just a different horse of a different color.

Did you, you know, and usually when people take a look at their career, they say, well, I was at the right spot at the right time, or at the wrong spot at the wrong time, and they say, in some cases, well, my career was determined more by luck than by the actions that I took myself.
Do you think that luck or fate is more important than your own
your own work, your own hard work?
No, I think fate has some point, some factor in it.
But I think really and truly that the end result is largely due to the effort you make.
To the effort you make, the extra effort you make, the enthusiasm you put into the endeavor.
And I think you can fairly well control that.
by your own.
But luck does play a part.
And it probably is not a constant either.
It probably in some situations plays a bigger part than in others.
It does play a part.
You became a general.
Did you consider yourself at the time while you were rising in your career, did you consider yourself ambitious?
I guess you'd have to say that.
But I don't think I was ever ambitious to where I was overly ambitious that I would step on somebody's toes or do somebody in to gain a brownie point or to gain an advantage.
I think that, well, the biggest mistake that senior military guys have
both in the service and when they leave the service, is they think they're little tin gods.
They think they're just shit on a stick.
And they think they're somebody.
And it's sad, but that's the problem with most of them when they retire.
And that's why most of them can't get a job.
Because no job is good enough for them.
They don't want to get their hands dirty.
They don't want to be down and be humble.
I bet when I first came down here, and I still do, I love to do it.
I love to go out and call on customers.
I bet I'm the only general that sold plastic fittings or that sold leather cups.
And hell, it doesn't bother me to walk in somebody's stranger's office and introduce myself and try to convince him to buy a product that we make or we sell.
But the average flag officer would think that was below his dignity or below his decorum to do that.
And they had an exalted opinion of themselves.
And that problem was evident.
both in the service and it's certainly evident out of the service.
How do you get rid of that feeling?
That feeling, I was an enlisted man in the service, and I could tell that just around the captain of my ship.
When I was in the Navy, it was very hard to communicate.
For most of us in the enlisted corps, it was very hard to communicate with our captain and our XO.
We could communicate with the junior officers, but they even had trouble communicating
What are you going to do in the military?
I don't know.
That's a good question.
If we knew the answer to that, we could solve a lot of personnel problems.
We could solve a lot of communication problems.
Because a lot of things go unattended to on the ship because of that lack of communication.
And a lot of things go unattended to in a command.
because of that.

And goodness knows there's a lot of retired people that could make a contribution in civilian life if they just had the humility to get off their goddamn high horse and get right down and work with their fellow Americans and do it.
I have a couple of questions about the military, just the military itself and the changes over the last 30 years.
